case_vignette: An 9-month-old infant is brought to the physician because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash began on her trunk and spread to her extremities. Five days ago, she was taken to the emergency department for fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She was born at term and has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Current medications include acetaminophen. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and pulse is 120/min. Examination shows a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is shown. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash all over my body that started on my trunk and has spread to my arms and legs.
How old are you?
I'm 9 months old.
Do you have a fever or any flu-like symptoms?
I had a high fever and a seizure five days ago, but now my temperature is a bit elevated.
Has your child recently been in contact with anyone who was sick, or have they been to a childcare facility?
I don't have any details on contact with sick individuals or childcare attendance.
Are there any new foods, medications, or products that have recently been introduced to the child's routine?
I'm only taking acetaminophen right now.
Has the child been vaccinated according to the recommended immunization schedule?
Yes, my immunizations are up-to-date.
Does the rash itch, and are there any blisters or open sores associated with it?
The rash doesn't itch and there are no blisters or open sores.
Is the rash flat or raised, and does it have a particular pattern or color?
The rash is raised and red, and it turns white when you press on it.
Are there any other symptoms present such as coughing, runny nose, or diarrhea?
No, there are no symptoms like coughing, runny nose, or diarrhea.
Final Diagnosis: Roseola (Exanthem Subitum)

The baby is only taking acetaminophen at this time and their immunizations are up to date. trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is roseola, also known as roseola infantum or sixth disease, caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6).
